instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1989: What is A1989? A1989 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2018, 2019 with EMC 3124, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00850..
definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message: MacBook arrived with no screen backlight and liquid damage in the backlight circuitry around <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>. Replaced all corroded components, including <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>. Now the backlight works but only when I select a very low brightness setting. It disappears when the brightness setting is raised. <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> is at a constant 49V. I assume there is some issue with the pulse-width modulation?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message: Did you test with known good LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message: Yes, of course. All 3 assemblies I tested show the same behavior.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message:
Remove and check all resistors out of board (ohm scale).
Also check the traces between <CHIP>U8400</CHIP>, <DIODE>D8410</DIODE> and feedback resistors divider.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message: All resistors check out correctly (I replaced almost all since they were liquid damaged). What's your guess as to what causes the backlight to disappear when brightness is increased?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message:
PWM signal should be good, once you note backlight reaction; even is not the expected.

Maybe some corroded capacitors...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2019 Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1989</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with display backlight issue
threads.message: After carefully looking at the liquid damaged area, I found the culprit. There was some invisible corrosion on the via for the powers supply to <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT_D</SIGNAL>). It was only delivering 4V instead of 5.1V. Bridged with a jumper wire and backlight is back in full strength.
